author: udomuc

title: 5th Gen Clearance Bar
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Why? ... Because clicking scares me. Anyone who bought the 5th gen right as it came out, knows well that it had "a few" issues. Now it works great, but i still get scared at the sound of any clicking.
As the extruder moves left the feed tube will come into contact with the left rail wall, which is okay, but as it keeps going left, the feed tube would often fall below the rail making a click type noise. This clearance bar will allow the feed tube to just slide along the flat surface and prevent the it from ever falling below the rail.

The measurements should be accurate. But, I would start with a test print and let it get about 5mm tall. Need to make sure that the bottom part of the clip will hook onto the bottom part of the rail smoothly. Being just a few millimeters off on the proper distance of the bottom part of the clip can be the difference between an awesome clip that fits snugly to the machine, and another chunk of useless PLA that you have no idea what to do with.

Created for Ava by Uncle Les, these 4AVA ModuLes are a work in progress.  Please do not print at this time unless you are willing to experiment as they do not properly interlock yet.  They will, however, become a unique and useful Lego-like interlocking toy, building block, and maker resource in time.  
The blocks are arranged in a 3D checkerboard fashion that is denoted by code as "if (x+y+z%2) block();", or in other words just add up the sum of the integer positions of x, y, and z, then take the modulo 2 of that sum.  If the result is one, put a block there and if not, leave it empty.  This makes a 3D space filling checkerboard, neat huh?  
So far so good, however there is a problem.  We need to make the blocks be exactly the same size as the empty space between them to get a nice firm interlock.  This means subtract the nozzle diameter from the block size, arrange them into a brick as described by the modulus of sum above, and we're good to go right?  
Unfortunately if we just do that then the blocks fall apart easily as they are not held together by much, and they don't print well either.  Solutions are many, including running supports at the internal edges and putting a solid box in the middle, as well as many other possibilities.  
We can surely agree, however, that once the kinks are worked out of this intriguing interlocking block system, the possibilities are endless.  For example we can take any STL file, say of Mickey Mouse shape, intersect it using the intersection() operator with an encompassing 4AVA ModuLe, and the STL file shape of Mickey Mouse itself becomes a 4AVA ModuLe.  neat, huh?  Everything everywhere becomes joinable.  
So you can see the potential - I will revisit this topic to try to get it working properly, and I hope you will too!  
Les

description.text: For many small electronic projects, a 5 Volt (4.5) power source is required. Small microprocessors like ATtiny become very portable with this device. It is a simple rectangular block with a button cell shaped cavity and a small hole at the two ends. Two push pins take care of a proper connection and can be soldered to the curcuit. remixed_from.title: Printrbot Simple 1405 "TRI ROD MOD" with or without XL tower upgrade (first 1405 XL tower)

title: "TRI ROD MOD" For the Printrbot Simple 1405 "Jonbot"

description.text:
Hello! The wonderful work done by Threefer has inspired me to mash together a Tri Rod Mod for the Jonbot.   
Unfortunately, there is no bolt-on solution for the current Z Box from the Jonbot. So I redesigned the base to add the third rod. I did this by lining up all of Threefer's files in Sketchup and mashing an extra rod holder onto it. The box will need to be inverted 180 degrees for printing.   
I understand that Threefer has been working on a Jonbot version, so I would like to see how his compares to mine.   
Use everything from his mod except the lower Z rod and top Z rod mounts. This should be a relatively simple mod, and you can pair it with Danman1178 and my extended X rod spacing mod to have the most stable bot in the world!*  
Will be a WIP before I can test, but everything was good in CAD so I don't forsee any issues. Enjoy!  
*I highly doubt it would be the most stable bot, but it will definately be a solid, awesome machine!

description.text:
The "holo clock" design by ekaggrat is at http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:570797 I made a motor gear that fits the axle of the 28BYJ-48 5V stepper motor. In my case it was a press fit, so the M3 grub screw may be optional. I also modified the motor mount to allow for the motor bearing collar. Currently, this is a design in progress, and I have not made a final build yet. The Champagne Bottle Rocket is a fun gift that I created for the 40th birthday of our friend Ariane. Congratulations agian! To fire the first stage of this rocket, ignite the wax engines (aka candels) and sing happy brirthday.
To deploy the secound stage, release the safety wire and shake the bottle (It is not recomended to use an expensive fuel (aka champagen)).
Caution: In the third stage you might alter your gravity by sipping on it.

Print 3 of each part in your favorite color and glue them together. If you like, wrap your bottle with the heat insulator (aka aluminium foil) and glue the rocket parts to it.
I printed in 0.2mm layer hight due to a shedule that required rocket speed. But it would be better to take time for 0,1mm layer hight.

description.text: Customized version of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:58001 Created with Customizer! http://www.thingiverse.com/apps/customizer/run?thing_id=58001

This is a glue stick applicator, using a moist sponge to help distribute the glue in a thin and even layer.   
It annoyed me that the glue stick gave a rough texture to the print surface and actually held the prints a little too well. With this method you can easily apply just the right amount of glue, and maintain a super smooth surface print after print.  
I designed this for UHU sticks, but I guess most brands will work. Scale if needed. The center hole is 26 mm in diameter with a narrow part ca 24 mm.

Print this in your favorite material, PLA works fine for me even if PET was used for the pictures. Cut a strip of sponge to fit, and stick it in the applicator. Press/twist a glue stick into the center hole. Pour some water in the holder "vase". To wet the sponge you simply put the applicator in the holder and give it a gentle shake or two.  
I usually start with applying some glue in a diagonal pattern. Then I retract the gluestick a bit, and finish the print bed off with the wet sponge in straight lines from the center to the side edges.  
I designed this in Tinkercad, sliced with CraftWare and printed it on a CraftBot.

This is an updated version of my previous posable robot action figure - http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:64131 The joints have been completely redesigned, adding sturdiness with a more realistic degree of freedom so it can now balance on one foot without falling over. It's also more compact and a slightly different proportion to the previous design. Update - There's now an image with Vertex side by side with a Lego Hero Factory figure for size reference. Update 2 - I've uploaded a new upper leg stl that's not as unnecessarily dense as the previous file so hopefully there shouldn't be any problems slicing it. UPDATE 3 - There are 2 new zip folders one contains 3dm files of the whole figure and the other just contains the individual joints. Feel free to use these files to create your own designs. Update 4 - Inspired by Toy story I decided to add a name onto the foot of the action figure although I used the robots name instead of my own. I've added an image to illustrate.

The example pictured was sliced in makerware with 3 shells, 5% infill and 0.1mm layer height. No support material is needed.  
I would suggest if you're printing in PLA really lightly sand down each of the contact surfaces of the joints because the shiny surface of PLA can make the joints start to slip after a while. I'm not sure if ABS would require the same treatment.  
Certain parts like the hips and upper legs have pins to provide a friction fit for the two halves, on my print they required a bit of a sand to fit in place but I eventually ended up glueing them anyway.   
All the filament used was purchased from Faberdashery, the inserts are glow in the dark.

description.text: This metric drill gauge can be used to check the dimensional accuracy of a printer or the effect of layer height. Additionally, it can be used as a reference when designing holes for your creations. For example, when printed with my machine, what has been designed as a 3mm hole will actual print as a 2mm aperture. As such, I use this gauge as standard when incorporating holes into my designs. My printer consistently makes hole diameters 1mm smaller than specified over the range of this drill gauge. All hole dimensions were validated with a set of metric drill bits.

description.text:
Case for 2.5" HDD.
Printable in one pice.

Get one of those SATA to USB converters: http://de.eachbuyer.com/usb-2-0-to-sata-7-15-pin-adapter-cable-for-2-5-hdd-hard-disk-drive-p15696.html
(5€ free shipping worldwide)

Ptint until the cabe hole is hald done and inset your converter. (Pay attention, that the extruder does not chrash it. (Use avoid crossing preineters in Slic3r!)

Ptint until close under the first layer of the top cover. Put in your HDD and plug it into the converter.

Put some toiletpaper between the HDD and the walls to avoid rattling. and wait for the printer to finish.

DONE
If you likle this please allso see my version two! http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1375058
I can customize this to fit your specific HDD! Just leave a comment and we can talk!

comments.text:
When you are ready to print it, make sure, to remove the plastic covering of your SATA adapter, because if not it may be to high and interfer with your mooving extruder.
Allso make sure to insert the adapter before the hole of the cable outlet colses entierly!
Be patient! Insert your HDD just before the walls of the case are the hight if the HDD and therefore shortly before the first layer of the top cover. Otherwise it may interfer with your extruder!
The top cover will rest on the HDD and so there will be no sagging.
But make sure that your HDD is not too 'fat' for the case. Mine has 650GB, therefore a 650 has the best fit. Don't konw, but I guess differt capacities have different thikness?

First rule of plumbing club, you don't mess with systems you don't understand.

Every modification will take as long as it takes.
1 system per mod,
If this is your first night at Plumbing Club, you've got to plumb. This is intended for low pressure return pipes for grey water at approximately room temperature. Do not use on Gas (Propane, LPG, Butane, Domestic Gas supplies, or any combustable media). Do not use on hot water or central heating systems (temp >40°C ; If you do not understand what ">" or "°C" means, don't use this part!). Do not use on macerated sewage. Do not use in temps close to 0°C. Do not use under floorboards or similar situations where it cannot be seen, monitored or changed easily. This design is not suitable for use in Nuclear Power Stations or Satellite Applications. Basically, use this sensibly. I've used similar in hydroponics, and it works at low pressure (102KPa / 1ATM - if you don't know what a KPa is, or what 1 ATM is, please don't use this design). I'm saying "Grey Water Systems Only" - but that's an ass covering statement, if you feel your build is safe enough to use on other systems, I'm not your keeper. I'm just an idiot. description.text:
OpenBuilds V-Slot™ Modular Framing System
=========================

description.header: V-Slot is an Open Source, high quality extruded aluminum profile building block that has an extremely smooth linear v groove rail on all 4 sides.  It's precise, easy to work with and allows you unlimited design control through it's modular nature.
description.text:
V-Slot's building characteristics are much like traditional T-Slot but V-Slot then goes on to add new levels of functionality through it's internal v grooves that allow for linear motion.
V-Slot is compatible with readily available, off the shelf, T-Slot components! OpenBuilds™ Parts are now available in many easy to use and share formats!
Including STEP / IGES / SolidWorks / SketchUp Please see the OpenBuilds Parts Resource section here to grab'em. http://www.openbuilds.com/resources/categories/openbuilds-parts.5/
Thank you and all the best with your builds!
Mark Carew Example builds
OpenBuilds
www.OpenBuilds.com

description.header: V-Slot easily and quickly allows for creating mechanical assembly's and motion control systems for just about any type of platform you can imagine!
UPDATE - New file to download. SketchUp model includes examples of OpenRail mounted to the V-Slot Framing system. As well as the latest plate and wheel models. Enjoy!
description.text:
Building with V-Slot is much like working with lumber.
You can cut it with a chop saw, and simply just bolt together using a screwdriver. And it is compatible with readily available T-Slot components.
"V-Slot can be used for most projects, such as 3D printers, CNC engravers, laser cutters, camera sliders, robotics and furniture. It could increase functionality of your design and drive down the cost of projects as well as the assembly time." Download the SketchUp model files to design your own machines before you build them.

author: spu

description.text: My wife complained sometimes we don't have any chandeliers in the rooms. So this my attempts to create a chandelier.

All you need is
  • your 3D printer
  • one aluminum or steel rod
  • a drill
  • some copper wires
  • some E14 bulb sockets (ceramic if possible)
  • some LED bulbs

  • You can have a lamp with just one lampshade. Then all you need is to print a lamp.stl, put the E14 socket into it, tighten the wires and you're done.

  • You can also have a lamp with two lampshades. Then you should first think how these two will be connected together. And you'll need to print lamp.stl twice and lamp_holder_side.stl twice. Then you need some screws to put everything together. Sometimes you but the screws together with the E14 socket.

  • Or you may want to have a chandelier like I have. Then you need to print three lamp.stl, one lamp_holder_center.stl and also two lamp_holder_side.stl. If you're really mad, you take the aluminum rod and drill some holes into it. So then you can hide your wires into the rod.

Owl keychain.
Thanks earnason.

YMMV This will plug the hole left in the body when one decides not to mount an FPV camera. The nibs on the sides of the barrel are not designed to latch when pushed completely in. They're intended to crush/deform, to create a very tight fit when inserted through the hole. I only insert until the barrel end is flush with the inside of the body. Then, in gap between the underside of the "brim/rim" and the body, I put a few dabs of super glue. This will keep the cap from shooting into the body, if for some reason one one to hit a pole - or similar - possibly forcing the plug into wires and or electronics. It also makes it removable - with some force - in the event you decide to upgrade. Enjoy!

So, I was printing some bar clamps for the Prusa Mendel and an odd idea popped into my head and before I knew it, I was rubbing dry erase marker on the filament prior to printing. About half way through the build I noticed that the filament being laid down was changing color. It appears as though the filament is being extruded without any halt, error, or otherwise. The dyed filament adheres to the HBP of my Thing-o-matic just as regular filament would. The layering is identical, and no other errors or anomalies were visible. I am not encouraging anyone to do this due to the fact that I do not know if any residue remains in the extruder mechanism, or if any damage is being done to the machine. More testing will be done to see what is going on in terms of damage, fume addition, etc. This can be a very cool , and cheap way of dying filament especially pink which is expensive as you all know. I am using Expo low odor dry erase marker. I have only tried purple, black, and green. Purple comes out the best in an almost strawberry to a faded pink gradient depending on how much marker fluid you apply, the spacing, etc, etc. I can already see parts produced with national colors, or holiday themes... I AM NOT RESPONSIBLE FOR ANY DAMAGES THAT THIS PROCEDURE MIGHT CAUSE EITHER TO THE MACHINE OR ANY AND ALL PERSONS OPERATING SAID MACHINE! I AM UNAWARE OF ANY POSSIBLE SIDE EFFECTS OF THIS PROCEDURE, THUS PLEASE USE CAUTION...and don't blame me if your bot goes up in flames. :) Have Fun!
PS - My apologies for the poor image quality (webcam), I didn't have a camera on hand.

• Find dry erase marker.
  • Coat several inches of the filament starting at the mouth of the extruder (where you insert the filament).
  • Make Stuff
  • Show off your pieces
  • Enjoy

description.text:
If you're like me and own a Kossel Mini and want to build a T4 quadcopter, you're out of luck. The main body parts won't fit in your build area (17cm diam x 24cm tall). This is a rebuild of the main body to address that. It's also a one-piece body, which gives it incredible strength. Here's the maiden flight video. Keep in mind, this is with default PIDs and no tuning of the control rates. It's VERY touchy, and has a lot of power. (hovering with 10-20% throttle only!)
I've also added the bottom part of the Naze32 case thing, since that's my flight board, but I can easily add files with different flight controller cases on the top. The arms I remixed from the T4-DT750 remix, just tweaked them for better printing vertically. UPDATE:
THIS IS CRUCIAL, I forgot to mention that the arms are angled upwards at 10 degrees, basically emulating what Flite Test did with their angle brackets for multirotors. They mention the new flight characteristics in the Naze setup video. Find the video with all the information here INFO:
Printer issues resolved. However, after printing it appeared that the cavities to bring the cables from inside the arms to where the ESCs are have too sharp angles. I'll need to redesign those completely for prototype V2.
Don't worry, it'll be posted here as a new file. In the meantime, my youtube video is showing V1 with the ESCs ziptied to the underside of the arms.
Also, I need to design a landing gear. It's coming. Patience.

Printed at 0.2mm with 19% infill using Cura, no supports, 1mm shell thickness and was stiff like it was carved out of aluminum.  
Rotate the file along the X axis -90 degrees so that it prints with the flat part on the bottom - tends to work better ;)  
The cavities for battery and receiver should fit most components, but in case yours are bigger, I can try and adjust the size if you give me dimensions. I sized mine around the Multiplex M-Link DR-7 receiver and an nVision 2200mAh 3S. The battery compartment is too narrow and will be enlarged in the next version.  
I fly using HobbyKing DT-750 motors, 18A ESCs (TowerPro Mag8, discontinued, they were just lying around), and an Acro Naze 32.  
My Receiver is a Multiplex M-Link DR7, with twin antennas and telemetry built in.

title: Flexy-Finger Prosthesis
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: A finger prosthesis, designed to cover a partial amputation, and to be printed with a flexible filament such as Filaflex

• Two fully functioning hidden hinges.
  • Print-in-place without support.
  • Can be strung with tendon line for actuation.
  • Customisable bracer.
  • Scale to fit.
  • Quick print.
    • Thanks to Jeff Erenstone of Performance Orthopedic Design for his consultation along the design process. My entry into the Assistive Technology Challenge http://www.gyrobot.co.uk
    http://www.facebook.com/gyrobotuk

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

10%

Notes: The socket's rough dimensions when printed at 100% are Dia 21mm x 30mm long, so you can scale up or down to suit. The trick here is to make sure that the thin walls of the hinge areas are fully defined in your slicer of choice. I used Craftware 1.06 to slice these models with and extrusion width of 0.28mm so the thin walls were generated correctly. The Craftware setting file is attached. I also include the .gcode files for anyone to view if they wish.

Assembly Instructions - Finger The finger can be strung with tendon line (e.g. nylon) and anchored back to a wrist strap, or hand brace. Closing the residual finger will pull on the tendon line and close the digits of the prosthetic finger. Thread the tendon down though the red path and then use a thin wire paper clip bent into a hook to grab the tendon and pull back out the end to tie off. Once tied off, thread the tendon back down inside the prosthesis and out through the small exit hole on top. Thin wire paperclip bent into a hook tool. The reinforcing ring may or may not be of use, depending on how well the prosthesis fits the residual finger. The ring will help stop the flexible side walls of the prosthesis from collapsing when the tendon is pulled. Bracer The bracer can be adjusted in Customizer for your hand size and which partial finger/s you would like an attachment for.
It is designed to be printed flat in PLA and thermoformed around the back of your hand or wrist Straight off the print bed and ready for thermoforming. Submerge in hot water until soft, use tongues/spatula etc to remove and form to shape required shape Fitted around back of hand Provides anchor point/s to attach a tendon line to.

comments.text: Being an active member of e-NABLE, thermoforming has been a revelation in producing cheap 3D printed custom fit "prosthetics". There is a trade off choosing PLA between it's "safe" low glass transitioning temperature (about 60deg C, not boiling water) and the fact that the that hands can soften if left in a car on a hot sunny day. A higher glass transition temperature is preferred for hot climate durability but not during the patient custom forming stage.

title: Tatami Tilings Set: Square Grid, 1x1 Monomino and 1x2 Domino Tiles

description.text:
A tatami tiling is a covering of the grid with domino tiles (1x2) and monomino tiles (1x1) so that NO FOUR TILES MEET.  
It turns out these configurations are so interesting, mathematically, that there was ample material for me to do my PhD on them!  
I also like to make stuff, so here are some models that will help you play around with them.  
The shape of this grid and these tiles makes it quick and easy to make configurations.  Print the grid with a colour that contrasts to the colours so that you can see the grid lines in between tiles.  
The tatami condition "NO FOUR TILES MEET" is equivalent to covering the grid with tiles so that the visible grid lines do not form '+' shapes.  You can see the '+' shape in one of the example tilings.

If  your printer can do a nice 45 degree overhang, go ahead with the 1 piece files.  Otherwise, print the tiles in two pieces and stick them together for a nicer finish.  
I've included the source files in case someone wants to make a derivative.

author: driggers

title: Prusa i3 Hephestos - Z Axis Motor Foot

description.text:
--CASTELLANO--
En la Prusa i3 Hephestos, entre la mesa y los motores del eje Z, queda un espacio que, aunque no supone ningún problema, en mi opinión queda "feo". La verdad es que sin proponermelo, además de mejorar el aspecto estético, conseguí que la impresora tuviese mejor estabilidad y vibrase menos durante la impresión
Una vez diseñado el pie, se me ocurrió añadir dos pequeños bolsillos para poder tener ordenadas dos tarjetas SD.
--ENGLISH--
In Prusa i3 Hephestos, between the table and Z axis motors, there is a space that, although it's not a problem, in my opinion is quite "ugly". The truth is that without meaning to, this pieces improve the esthetic appearance, the printer is more stable and vibrates less during printing
Once designed the foot, I thought to add two small pockets to place two SD cards.

title: Telescope Sun Screen for Projecting Images of the Sun

description.text: For the upcoming solar eclipse in march 2015 I build this screen to be able to watch the sun in a g group of people. NEVER LOOK DIRECTLY INTO THE SUN WITH OR WITHOUT OPTICAL INSTRUMENTS! Also be aware that even when such a screen us used the heat of the sun can cause damage to your telescope, so please use any measures to not let too much light into your telescope (usually a lens cap with a smaler opening) Supervise your audience especially small childs!

Use the Blend file to customize for your telescope. I added a slightly larger mounting (33mm diameter) for easy fit on some eye pieces. Parts you need:
  • carbon tube 5mm diameter
  • 6 M2 bolts and nuts
  • 2 M3 bolts
  • M4 bolt and nut/lock nut
  • screen material
    • Assembly:

  • cut out screen material, you may use thicker paper, I used a PVC foil, one side is matte which is good. Of course a opaque material is better but this semi transparent makes it possible to look at the image from behind.

  • tap the two M3 threads for the carbon tube

  • assemble all :-)

title: MakerBot Replicator 2 - PLA blue frogs - Layer thickness comparison plate

description.text:
This is a simple vector graphics file that you can lasercut. It was designed to hold four of MorenaP's cute treefrog model, one in each layer height as you can choose in MakerWare and also a 50 micron version.
  • 0.34 mm/layer - Low (340 microns)
  • 0.27 mm/layer - Medium (270 microns)
  • 0.1 mm/layer - High (100 microns)
  • 0.05 mm/layer - Super fine (50 microns)
    • These models where 3D printed with blue 1.75 mm PLA plastic filament on a MakerBot Replicator 2 3D printer.
    Video
  • https://vimeo.com/63248061
  • http://youtu.be/hMXkRY8sWZQ
    • The sample 3D model for this print is MorenaP's popular tree frog:
  • http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:18479
    • By Creative Tools

  • Home - Things - GooglePlus - Twitter - Facebook - Youtube - Instructables - Instagram - Flickr - Vimeo - LinkedIn

• Laser cut the plate
  • 3D-print the frogs
  • Glue them on the plate
  • Touch them... but don't lick them. Frogs ar dangerous to lick or kiss!

comments.text: I've also found that printing at lower layer height can substantially decrease the filament expenditure, especially with huge models.  I'm not sure why this is, but it seems the only downside to tiny layers is that it takes forever to print with them.
comments.author: Malcolm3DPrinting

comments.text: How did you arrive at 0.27 and 0.34 mm layer heights?
comments.author: jwx23

comments.text: At the time this test and video was made (Apr 3, 2013) the MakerWare software had these layer heights as default values.

comments.author: Dominik86

comments.text: Depending on what speed is used in can vary. We 3D printed a whole colony of frogs at 50 microns layer height. A single frog took 1 hour and 48 minutes. Placing several frogs on the build platform and printing them in one go reduces the time per frog.

comments.text: We don't share the STL file because we did not make it. We merely borrowed MorenaP's 3D model and used it for printing different resolutions since is it such a great model. The only thing we made was to produce the 3D prints and a 2D file for those who want to laser cut a plate for the frogs. (which we have shared)

title: D5S Fan Housing with air deflector MK2

description.text:
Here is a MK2 version of my Wanhao D5S fan housing.  
NOTE THERE ARE NOW 2 VERSIONS AVAILABLE.  
29mm & 32mm THIS IS THE DIMENSION FROM CTR OF THE NOZZLE TO THE MOUNTING SCREWS. MEASURE FIRST AND PICK THE RIGHT ONE FOR YOU. (Thanks to ElBertie for supplying the info for the 32mm version)  
This is more compact than the MK1 version and will not foul the side frame at the rear left corner.  
This fan housing centralizes the air flow at the nozzle rather than being offset like the standard Wanhao one.  
This also stops the temp drop as the fan kicks in so no need to insulate the hot end.

I printed this on my Wanhao D5S Mini with the following settings 100% infill
2 outer shells of 0.4mm
No supports Custom marlin firmware.
Simplify3d custom settings 0.2mm Layer height med quality settings Time to print 114 mins Should print fine at 50% infill like the MK1

I printed this using ABS plastic with my XYZ Da Vinci 1.0 printer. The print time was ~2 hours and used 6.3m of plastic. Make sure to scale the dimensions to 101% (1% increase in scale) to adjust for shrinking of the plastic. Rotate the cover so that the main face (the back of the cover) is laying down on the printing surface. Fits to the iPhone 5 perfectly without any sliding around inside.

description.text:
Parts to replace melamine arm with proper spool holder.  
Requires M8 threaded rod, nuts, and 608 skate bearings.  
Getting the rod holes level was pretty challenging.  Would appreciate feedback from someone who has tried this as I haven't printed it again since making some tweaks.  
Note, for ABS, scale to 102% before slicing - so everything will fit properly!  
Also, the Rostock Max v2 is built in english units, not metric - whee!

Print one each of the inside & outside pieces.  Print 2x of the spool holders - enable support for these so the bearing holes will print well.  
Need about 7" of M8 threaded rod, a few M8 nuts (as few as 3-4 could work), and qty 2 608 skate bearings.

title: DaVinci XYZ Z axis screw top support

description.text:
I noticed that the z axis screw wiggle some since its hold in place in just two spot , this is a support who eliminate 60 -70% of the wiggle of the screw , after printing must file the insides to accomodate the screw , since I didn't want it too loose I made it slightly tighter , he has a hole for a M4 nut inside  
printed at 0,3 solid , 40 minutes print

comments.text: Printed it successfully without support (but with the help of a cooling fan). I didn't need to file to fit the screw, it was just a perfect fit. Not so much for the M4 nut though, that one required some careful cutting and filing. I'm not really sure whether this provides any real benefit but anyway, have installed it and will see how it goes :)

author: KnightwithouthFilament

description.text:
A set of amulets based on six fold terdragons. Six fold terdragons are easily constructed. Six copies of a terdragon, (see thing:67886), are stacked and a center of overlap is chosen. Each copy in turn is rotated by a multiple of 60 degrees around the center and the six copies are combined. The result is an an attractiver object with a 6 fold rotation axis. Six fold terdragons have been studied for use as broadband antennae. Here are four based on first, second, third, and fourth order terdragons. They are scaled to be approximately the same size. 6one_15_4.stl
6two_10_2.stl
6three_5_15.stl
6four_25_75.stl Also included is a larger version of the fourth order amulet, 6four_8_2.stl. The individual terdragons were constructed using terdragon_3d.scad from thing:67886. Rotate_60.scad is the program that took six second order terdragons and created 6two_10_2.stl. Its input was two_10_2.stl.
The curves are best printed directly on the build platform.

A fixed key lathe metric type 9x9 mm, useful to remove tools from the turret. Thanks

title: Crampons for  Winter Trail snowshoes by GV

description.text:
Crampons for  Winter Trail snowshoes by GV - more of a test than anything else. My local fire chief was frustrated by the metal crampons getting packed with frozen snow and wanted to try plastic ones. I redesigned from the ground up, attempting to give enough strength and stability.   
I didn't take pics of the final prints, but I printed at 0.25mm/layer and 80% infill. There's a little flexibility at the hollow arch, but not sure how that will handle. The rest is very strong.

author: marks47

description.text: Knobs to hang stuff on the wall.

Female in the house hold needed something to organize her brooms on, so I designed this. It should be printable without supports.  
The design features mounting holes to clear a M5 machine screw, witch is what our plaster wall anchors use.
Used Slic3r to make gcode for my Ormerod printer, fitted it with some white PLA and press play on tape.

Splendor is a fantastic tabletop game, but the box for the game has a bit of wasted space which reduces the portability of the game. I was inspired to create this design after seeing a post where someone on reddit created a minimalist foamcore organizer for the game: https://www.reddit.com/r/boardgames/comments/2w5zgy/foam_core_minimalist_box_for_splendor/. The organizer cover can be easily held in place with a small box band: http://www.flyingbuffalo.com/other.htm I recommend printing the cover flipped upside down so that supports are only needed under the lettering. If you don't have access to a 3D printer, these organizers are available on Etsy: https://www.etsy.com/listing/223848228/splendor-game-organizer

comments.text: Great thing! How did you make that ?
comments.author: RElabFabLabLiege

comments.text:
If you mean "How did I print that?" I haven't yet. I usually print these things with supports and then clean them up.
If you mean "How did I create that?" I used Mathematica. I have been using Mathematica since the early 90's to solve various problems that I have worked on. Recently I came up with some code that draws a tube with hemispherical end caps that I can put wherever I want. Then a small bit of code lets me give a list of points in space and a list of which points need to be connected by one of these tubes. So to create this I just needed to come up with the coordinates of the vertices of the platonic solids. Mathematica then allows export to a .stl file.

title: Better Printrbot Simple Metal Spool Holder

description.text: Better Printrbot Simple Metal Spool Holder

I fixed mayermi design for his Printrbot Simple Metal Spool Holder. Things I did:
  • Resized the holes. They were about 13.1mm and should fit a 12mm rod. I made them 12.5mm.
  • Changed the space between the two holes from 71mm to 70mm.
  • Alterted the fase to 50° so it can be print easier without support.
  • Designed a "washer" for the bearings. Now the spool can't slip off the bearings.
    • bill of materials:
  • 2 x M8 screws to secure the holder
  • 4 x M8 Screws (8x45mm)
  • 8 x washers
  • 8 x 608ZZ bearings
  • 8 x M8 nuts
    • I stacked them this way: nut - washer - bearing - bearing - washer - nut.

Printed with Printrbot Simple Metal:
  • 0.2mm layerheight
  • 2 ouline/perimeter shells
  • 50% Infill
  • 25% support for the holes
  • black PLA at 185°C
    • washer.stl should be printed 8 times.
    Make sure the washer is correctly layed down on your printbed.

This is a drafting tool that enables you to place 11 equally spaced points along a line, creating 10 equal length segments.  These tools are typically made out of stainless steel with riveted pins and cost upwards of $200.  This version will get the job done for a fraction of the cost!

To construct a ten point divider of your own, start by printing out all of the pieces in your desired colors.  If a quantity is indicated in the part file name, then print that number of multiples (e.g. "7x" means print 7 of them), otherwise only print one.  Assemble the divider by inserting "LinkPin" components into the holes and glue the "Plug" component on into the holes with epoxy or super-glue.  Be careful not to get glue in the joint!

Einfache und effektive Art ABS mit Aceton zu Glätten.
Version 1 ist die Low Budget Variante mit 2 Aluförmchen und vielen Reisszwecknadeln.
Version 2 ist die High End Variante mit gefederten Nadeln auf einer Platine.
Vorgehen: Ständer in Wasserkocher stellen. ABS Figur auf die Nadeln legen und mit einem KLEINEM Schuss Aceton Abrunden (Vorsichtig an der Wand entlang...).
Deckel schliessen und kurz Wasserkocher einschalten bis ihr ein zischendes Geräusch hört.
Anschliessend noch 1-5 Minuten, je nach gewünschten Ergebnis, warten. Deckel öffnen und ausdampfen lassen...fertig.
Das Werkstück noch nicht berühren, sondern noch für weitere 10 Min ausdampfen lassen.
ACHTUNG: Nur im Freien durchführen, da Aceton reizend auf die Haut, Augen und Lungen wirkt. Die Entzündungsgefahr ist relativ gering, da die Dämpfe zu keiner Zeit die Zündtemperatur von 500°C erreicht. Aber: Nicht in der Nähe offenes Feuer (Rauchen)! Viel Spass! Info translated to english: Simple and effective way ABS with acetone to smoothing. Version 1 is the low budget version with 2 Aluförmchen and many rice -purpose needles. Version 2 is the high end version with spring-loaded pins on a board . Procedure : Place rack in a kettle. ABS lay figure on the needles and with a SMALL shot acetone rounding ( carefully along the wall ... ) . Close the lid and shortly kettle switch until you hear a hissing sound stopped. Then for 1-5 minutes , depending on the desired result , wait. Open the lid and let evaporate ... done . Not touch the workpiece , but can still evaporate for 10 min. CAUTION : Only perform outdoors as acetone irritant effect on the skin , eyes and lungs. The risk of ignition is relatively low, as the vapors at any time reached the auto ignition temperature of 500 ° C. But not near open flames (smoking ) ! Have Fun! Thanks for translation: mb20music

comments.text:
Im Internet habe ich noch eine kalte Methode gefunden:
Einfach in eine verschliessbare Plastik Box 2-3 mit Aceton getränkte Tücher hängen, Box verschliessen und 5-10 Stunden warten. Werde es bald einmal ausprobieren.

comments.text:
Die Spitzen bohren sich ins ABS, dagegen kann man nichts machen. Folgendes bessert aber das Erscheinungsbild:
-Das Objekt sollte leicht (mit wenig Infill) gedruckt werden
-Die Einwirkzeit des Acetons sollte nicht über 5 min liegen
-Die Nadeldichte sollte hoch sein damit sich das Gewicht gleichmässig verteilt

author: djbiohazard

description.text:
I recently upgraded to a MakerGear Prusa Mendel from a Cupcake CNC with an automated build platform, and I missed the automatic ejection of parts out the front. So I designed a super-sized conveyor platform, re-using the gearmotor and also making use of AVataRR's paper + kapton belt design. Video of it working: http://natetrue.posterous.com/automated-prusa-mendel-3d-printer-win-go-prus In addition to the printed parts, it also requires:
  • A Kysan DC Gearmotor A20RU-12V36RPM-15.5 (same one as the Cupcake's ABP)
  • 200mm and 212mm lenghts of 1/2" EMT electrical conduit from a local hardware store
  • 3x M4x20 bolts
  • 6x M4 nuts
  • 3x 624ZZ bearings (4mm x 13mm x 5mm)
  • 5x M3x15 bolts
  • 1x M3 nut
  • Quite a bit of polyamide/kapton tape (the wider the better)
  • Some silicone sealant or rubber cement
    • Known issues:
  • The DC gearmotor is almost not powerful enough
  • Sometimes the belt 'wanders' one way over time and gets gummed up against the roller holders
  • A belt this big doesn't stay very even

Print the STL part bed, dust off your outdated 2D printer and print three copies of the PDF for the belt, and buy all the other parts.
For each of the 3 roller holders, screw in an M4 screw and add two nuts around a 624 bearing as shown in the picture.  Drill holes into the wooden platform holder (you may need to re-imagine the mounting if you don't have a specifically MakerGear Prusa) for the mounts flush along the left edge of the platform.  Make sure to align the mounts like they are aligned in the Blender file, with the shorter roller holders along the front edge of the platform and their beveled side facing up.
Put the 200mm piece of tubing between the roller holders and make sure it can spin freely and loosely. The 624 bearings aren't big enough to fill the pipe but they will hold it in the right place under tension.
Mount the larger roller holder on the rear left of the platform, assembled the same as the other two.
Locate the gear with the longer, skinnier shaft and jam it down one end of the 212mm tube, so that the entire shaft is in the tube.  You can add a set screw if you want but it should be a very snug fit.  Put the tube through the hole in the motor mount so that the gear is facing to the right and the mounting screw holes are facing downward, as modeled in the Blender file.  Mill out the hole if the tube is too tight. It should spin freely in the hole.
Drill holes in the board and use M3 screws (or good wood screws) to mount the motor holder as modeled.
Take the other gear and put an M3 nut in the slot so that it lines up with the set screw hole and use an M3 bolt as a set screw.  Mount the motor on the motor mount so that the gear is facing outward and meshes with the other gear.
Apply power to the motor to test that it turns the roller properly. If it gets stuck, make sure the holes are big enough and nothing's in the way.  After that, rub a thin layer of silicone sealant or rubber cement on the motorized roller where the belt will contact it.  Allow to dry completely and then play with it with your fingers to make sure it's not super sticky still.
Take the three parallelogram printouts and cut them on the lines.  Figure out how to orient them so they are the right size on the platform and tape them in a line.  Thread it around the rollers and platform and pull it tight with your fingers; mark where you need to cut the belt and cut it, then tape it together into a loop.
Test the motor again - it should turn the belt nicely.
Now, cover the belt with the Kapton tape using strips lengthwise along the belt.  It helps to remove the motor gear so you can freely move the belt around.  Try not to overlap the tape nor have gaps of much paper showing.  The goal is a nice smoothly covered belt.
Once everything's assembled, connect the motor to output D10 of your RAMPS electronics (or similar). It should be the pins controlling the cooling fan.  Use a variant of the end gcode provided (my start is also here but it's not very relevant to the conveyor).  Essentially it moves to the end of the Y axis, waits 30 seconds, then runs the conveyor for 10 seconds.

This brings me to a question:  May I ask why you use gears in this design instead of a straight drive from the motor to an adapter, and then to the tube?  Is there an issue with direct drive I haven't thought of yet, or is it just a way to fold things over so they don't hit something particular to the Mendel design?
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: There are parts on either side of the platform that would interfere with a more direct drive.  The gears are a weak point of the design and slippage is real common for me, also binding of the gear teeth.  If you can manage a direct drive, go for it! That'd make this thing much more reliable.  I am thinking of going with a bigger diameter roller in the rear and stuffing the gear motor inside of it, though I'm not sure how exactly that would work out.

description.text:
Disclaimer:
Due to the recent incidents (things appearing on ebay) I just want to make something very clear:
I do not allow any commercial use of my STL-files, my designs and my photos! Description:
Sometimes you just need a light in the dark.
Now you can print your own lantern. And if you add some parts it even shines! The lantern model is quite large. To print it you have to resize it. I printed the lantern at 30% and the result is still ok.
Print the glass part with transparent PLA if you want to make it shine. For the light you need
1x LED 5mm
1x matching resistor for the LED
1x 1.5F, 5.5V goldcap capacitor
1x USB micro B port Solder the USB port, the capacitor and the LED (+ resistor) in parallel. Now you can charge your lamp with power from your USB port. A 10 seconds charge will make the LED shine for at least 10 minutes.

author: jleach86

title: Hexagon hot end shroud for MakerFarm i3 i3v Wade's Extruder

description.text:
The stock shroud provided with the MakerFarm hexagon-style hot end suffers in that it clips onto the heat tube of the hot end. This causes the shroud to soften and melt, often dropping onto the hot end aluminum block where the melted shroud often drips onto the print or print bed.  The oversized fan and shroud also allow a lot of airflow to bypass the hot end heatsink, reducing the amount of cooling actually obtained.  
Two alternatives to the stock shroud are provided here.  Both use a 25mm fan such as a 3 CFM Sunon MAGlev MC25101V2-000U-A99 to exhaust heated air towards the front of the printer.  Both mount to the front of the MakerFarm Wade's Extruder base using the same mounting holes as the stock 40mm hot end fan.  
File hex_shroud_flush allows the 25mm fan to mount flush to the shroud bracket.  File hex_shroud_angle10 adds a spacer block that tips the fan upwards by 10-degrees, minimizing the possibility of fan exhaust from hitting the front of the heat bed.  
Note that the rear shroud component differs between the two designs. The flush mount style has a round inlet hole to match the fan.  The angled mount has the round inlet on the angle plate, and is designed for a better fit with the angled fan mounting screws.  
These shrouds are intended for use with the MakerFarm i3/i3v X-axis carriages that use a wood shelf along with an aluminum grooved plate for the hot end mount.  Most corners are rounded for consistency with the MakerFarm design style. Suitability for other hexagon hot end applications has not been verified.

Test prints were accomplished with Simplify3D using a 0.40mm nozzle, 0.20mm layer height, and 20% infill.  Use of support should not be required; the maximum length of unsupported extrusion is around 4mm.  Test prints shown in the gallery were printed with MakerBot Natural 1.75mm PLA at a temperature of 225 degrees.  
A 10mm-deep fan like the Sunon MAGlev mounts to the flush-mount shroud with 12mm long machine screws.  For the angled mount, 16mm and 20mm screws are required.  For both types, the upper screws must not extend through the plate of the shroud or they will interfere with the wood shelf of the X-carriage.   Fan mounting holes are sized for use with M2.5 or #3 machine screws.  Depending on the amount of first-layer "squish" for a given printer, the machine screws should thread into the shroud without reaming or tapping - just provide the right amount of encouragement.   If there's a bit of squish to the first layer and a heated bed is used during printing, the holes will likely be undersized and #2 machine screws might also work.   
For the angled mount, the fan mounts to the angled top-side of the printed part.  Sand or file the top surface as required to provide an airtight fit against the fan.  
The fan should be mounted so that airflow is pulled from the hot end area and exhausted to the front of the printer.   This keeps fan exhaust from affecting the print area under the X-carriage.   
The shrouds are designed for a clearance fit around the hexagon heatsink on the hot end.  The heatsink needs to be oriented so that a point on the hexagon faces forward.  Orientation of the heatsink with respect to the aluminum block can be adjusted by loosening the heat break tube and nozzle at the aluminum block, repositioning and re-tightening.  
The clearance fit around the hexagon heatsink should keep the bottom of the shroud from softening.  Newer hexagon hot ends come with an insulation boot; proper fit with the boot has not been tested.  I have always used a few layers of kapton tape to insulate the aluminum block.  Extreme installations might benefit from installing some fiberglass sheeting between the bottom of the shroud and the aluminum block as additional insulation.  An insulator could also be formed by wrapping kapton tape on itself a few times to create a thick ribbon of kapton, slicing it partway and trimming a hole for the heat break tube, and slipping it between the aluminum block and the shroud.   
Make sure the shroud is tightened to the X-carriage when it is up as high as it will go.  
I prefer to keep all fins on the heatsink exposed, so I don't recommend using fiberglass or kapton sheeting between the heatsink and the shroud unless it is proven to be necessary.

comments.text: Thank you for posting this. I was looking to design a different fan shroud myself because I don't like the stock one. Bonus is I already have a 25mm fan waiting for this use.

description.text:
This 3D printed model features the old World Trade Center Complex. All 7 buildings were destroyed on September 11th 2001. WTC 1 & 2 = 110 stories, WTC 3 = 22 stories, WTC 4 = 9 stories, WTC 5 = 9, WTC 6 = 8 stories & WTC 7 = 47 stories. All 4 towers were almost completely destroyed. Please let this aid your research into the destruction of the World Trade Center complex. The pictured model was printed on a ProJet 1500 3D printer. title: Raspberry Pi breakout frame for MLAB

description.text:
3D Printable Breakout frame which mechanically adopts Raspberry Pi models A and B which have two mount holes to MLAB (http://wiki.mlab.cz/) electronic prototyping and development system.
The holder uses the M2.5 screws for fastening the RaspberryPi board to the breakout frame. The breakout frame accepts standard M3x12mm screws and nuts which are used normally in MLAB system.

The breakout frame is designed to be easily printable on almost all 3D FDM printers, it can be printed from ABS or PLA plastic with good result. But an inspection of trace placement in thin walls is required after slicing. The model has bottom holes for nuts covered by one layer of material. This technological material allows slicing software to plan a bridge over all holes. The bridge layer must be drilled of after printing by a 3mm drill the 2.7mm drill would be used for drilling the Raspberry Pi mounting holes. Hexagonal nuts should be inserted from bottom side to the prepared holes. Two M2.5x12mm screws for mount the Raspberry Pi board should be screwed from the top side. Other file formats and thing up to date sources are freely available from MLAB's SVN Repository. The MLAB's dural base board is available there http://www.ust.cz/shop/product_info.php?products_id=177 as example.

It is available for free (also no advertisements) on the Google Play Store for all Android devices (sorry no iOS). https://play.google.com/store/apps/details?id=appinventor.ai_carlfranc.taq3DPRINTCALC_V1a&hl=it (this is the italian link, if is not accessible from you make a search with the app name) I took inspiration on calculators already available on various HTML pages that are mentioned in the About page of the application. This is my Funbot built using 3/8" rods/tubes and bronze bushings. The default STL's for the funbot are already 3/8" which makes it nice. I wanted to use bronze bushings, so I made an adapter from the bronze bushings to the LMU10 bearings it's designed for. I bought the bushings and 12" stainless rods(Z Axis) and 12" aluminum tubes(X & Y Axis) from servocity.com. I'm not sure yet how well the aluminum tubes are going to work, so you might just want to get the stainless rods for all axis until I have tested it. I bought a couple 8"x8"x1/8" aluminum plates for the bed and had a 11.5"x12"x1/2" aluminum plate for the base. My base is way too thick, but I had it already. A 1/4" thick plate would have been better. I wanted a Bowden extruder, so I made a simple mount that mounts over the Spool Plates and still lets them adjust. It holds the extruder in a 45 degree angle to hopefully help with the filament feeding. I've followed Cliff's video build tutorials for assembly. I'm no 3d designer, so I'm including the SCAD files in hopes it allows other to tweak/fix/upgrade what I've done easily. 3/8"x3/4" Bronze Bushings AGB-A2-20 $1.75 https://www.servocity.com/html/bronze_bushings.html
3/8"x12" Stainless Rods 634222
$5.89 https://www.servocity.com/html/3_8__precision_shafting.html
3/8"x12" Aluminum Tubes 635250 $3.99 https://www.servocity.com/html/3_8__hollow_aluminum_tubing.html
The bed plates I purchased off ebay. I recommend using the Z carriage with TR8 Leadscrew from Djinn5150's remix.
He also has a nice Hotend holder, X Belt tensioner available
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1181189 All wired up now. Just need to calibrate and print! Link to the Funbot Build Thread
http://forums.reprap.org/read.php?166,429588,469445#msg-469445 First Print Video
http://youtu.be/dOjd456S570 Printing Zombie Hunter. Still haven't tuned it.
http://youtu.be/E2vOD2z6caE http://youtu.be/RQfkIAslGjQ I think I have the Slicer config working pretty good now for the Bowden Extruder. The Retract and Support settings are really working good for this printer. So, I've included the Sli3er config and bundle. You will need to change the Bed Size and Nozzle size for your build. Added a pic of 3D Benchy Printed with this Config. Updates:
10/27/15 Made a change to the extruder support for easier printing 11/12/15 Added Hotend Mount that works with Chinese style E3d Hotends and has a mount for Inductive Sensor for autobed leveling. The Inductive Sensor is offset 23mm from the Hotend on the Y axis.

comments.text: I had a Smartrap. But it was just too flimsy. That's why I built a Funbot. It's very stable. I finally converted the Funbot STL's to use the M8 rods on my Smartrap, and took it apart to build the M8 Funbot. Still very stable. So far I've built 4 Funbots. So you know how I feel about them. Watch Cliff's build videos from the original design to get an idea of how it all goes together. I've only built Bowden versions and suggest to all that build them to use Bowden too. Hanging a big heavy stepper on the X axis only supported on one side might give problems. The Bowden tube itself is pretty short so it doesn't give much issues when setting things up. If you have any questions on your build, just let me know.
